ECOSYSTEM Infrastructure Construction & Product Ecosystem


The Infrastructure Construction Ecosystem

Info Tech Systems business primary market is infrastructure construction. Our customers are the government “owner” agencies and private companies involved in building and maintaining infrastructure such as roadways, bridges, airports, and so on. This is the ecosystem within which our customers do business. Following is a “twenty thousand foot” orientation on the ecosystem.

In most cases the “owner” we service is a government agency such as the Florida Department of Transportation. So while the owners may not own the infrastructure in the strict legal sense, we use that blanket term to refer to them. Due to budget and staffing constraints many owners employ consultants to support the owner’s infrastructure construction and maintenance activities in a variety of roles.

Then there are those who perform the construction: the contractors who do the work and suppliers who supply the required materials and components. The “prime” contractor is the contractor to whom the owner awarded the construction project contract. The prime contractor is contractually accountable for the entire project outcome, including what the suppliers provide and the work performed by other contractors to whom the prime contractor subcontracted part of the work.

AASHTOWare Project is focused on meeting the needs of AASHTO’s members: state-level infrastructure owner agencies such as the Florida Department of Transportation. Info Tech’s “ITI Products” services facilitate the interactions between the state-level owner agencies and the companies who do the work. ITI Products services also address the needs of “local” infrastructure owners such as counties and cities.

The following diagram illustrates the primary relationships between the owners and the other construction project participants and the degree to which each uses ITI Products and AASHTOWare Project. (Click the diagram for a larger view.)



In cases where a local owner agency is managing a construction project (a.k.a. “job”) that is in any way funded with federal or state level funding, the state-level owner agency is responsible for insuring that the project is properly run. In those cases the state-level agency may require the local agency to use AASHTOWare Project to manage the project.

The Product Ecosystem

Construction projects go through a series of lifecycle stages: planning/design, preconstruction, bidding, and construction. Once construction is complete the assets that were built move into a management/maintenance stage. Click the diagram to drill down into more about these phases, the role of ITI Products and AASHTOWare Project in the phases, and which project participants use the products and services when. (Click the diagram for a larger view.)
